title: It should be possible to get a mutable reference to a ZST literal

labels.name: T-types
labels.description: Relevant to the types team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
The following code is legal:

```rust
fn get_mut_ref<'a>() -> &'a mut [u8] {
    &mut []
}
```

However, if we instead use `()`, it's no longer legal:

```rust
fn get_mut_ref<'a>() -> &'a mut () {
    &mut ()
}
```

We get this error:

```text
error[E0515]: cannot return reference to temporary value
 --> src/lib.rs:2:5
  |
2 |     &mut ()
  |     ^^^^^--
  |     |    |
  |     |    temporary value created here
  |     returns a reference to data owned by the current function
```

Is there a reason that the former is legal while the latter is not? I would expect the latter to be legal - in the general case, it'd be great if it were legal for _any_ ZST, although I'm sure that's more complicated (especially in a generic context).

On Fuchsia, we're currently using [this hack](https://fuchsia-review.googlesource.com/c/fuchsia/+/741462/8/src/connectivity/lib/packet-formats/src/ipv6/ext_hdrs.rs#1154) to work around this limitation.
